data.author: ab76
data.content: Trinidad’s energy sector, which has suffered a significant decline over the past decade, still has plenty of life left in it. It’s not only Touchstone that’s been exploring for and finding significant new resources, but the large independents have been buying up assets (Perenco has invested billions over the past couple of years) and the majors have been busy. Exxon returned last August, Shell and BP never left, and Chevron and Total are interested. There’s even an increasing prospect that Trinidad’s refinery will reopen later this year (see https://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/After-Years-Offline-Trinidad-Looks-to-Indian-Oil-to-Restart-Refining.amp.html). Oil production is rising again and some major gas projects will soon come on line. Energy still makes up about half the economy and, although there are various ways to further improve the fiscal system, it’s not a bad place to do business (Touchstone, like other producers, has no transportation costs and is paid monthly in US dollars). I’m much more comfortable investing in Trinidad than, say, in a company producing oil in the jungles of Peru. The AIM has its flaws, but plenty of decent companies, including Touchstone, are listed on it. It’s far from untouchable and Warren Buffett, through CalEnergy, had a partnership with Parkmead Group (an AIM company).

data.author: rossannan
data.content: Sturm/G_G_G Buffett wouldn’t go anywhere near AIM though.  On AIM, if there even is FCF in the first place, predicting it involves a great deal of conjecture.  Working from historical FCF allows you to draw a more reliable trajectory while also assessing what was delivered at each stage against what was then expected. When significant positive change is promised or even just a possibility, it is tempting to load up in anticipation.  More often than not though you are better on the sidelines - in the event of disappointment you are well out while if significant positive change is actually delivered you will understand its significance and be able to get in ahead of those who don’t (likely buying the shares of the inevitable sellers into the news).

data.author: Sturm
data.content: Dunder, On stepped pricing that improves with volume and a conservative P/E of 3, CR-3 contributes ~$50m probability-weighted, or ~12p per TXP share, before any credit for follow-ons, VAT, or broader rerating, on these assumptions: Net gas rates to TXP: 5 / 10 / 15 / 20 mmcf/d Stepped realised gas prices (blended): 5 mmcf → $4.50/mcf 10 mmcf → $5.00/mcf 15 mmcf → $5.50/mcf 20 mmcf → $6.00/mcf NGL yield: ~5% of boe, NGL netback $40/bbl Forward multiple: P/E = 3 Shares outstanding: ~325m FX: $1 = £0.78 Probabilities: 5 mmcf: 25% 10 mmcf: 30% 15 mmcf: 20% 20 mmcf: 5% Failure: 20% Market cap on success (per tier) 5 mmcf → ~$26m 10 mmcf → ~$58m 15 mmcf → ~$96m 20 mmcf → ~$139m Probability-weighted market cap 0.25 × 26 = $6.6m 0.30 × 58 = $17.5m 0.20 × 96 = $19.2m 0.05 × 139 = $6.9m Failure = $0 ➡ Total ≈ $50m probability-weighted Per-share value $50m ÷ 325m shares ≈ $0.155/share Converted to GBP ≈ ~12.0p per share

data.author: John2727
data.content: There’s no argument that earlier expectations were optimistic. But today TXP is a very different company. Cascadura, Central Block and legacy production are all real, producing and cash-positive, and together they cover debt service - albeit without much slack. That’s exactly why management has prioritised stability over growth at this time. Central Block is already a meaningful cash contributor: while it represents roughly 40–45% of volumes, its lower operating costs mean it contributes a higher share of operating cash flow. With the main pipeline runs now complete and only final tie-ins and sign-off remaining, Central Block is well positioned to be the most efficient area for near-term growth. Some recent declines are operational rather than structural. The manufacturing fault on the Cascadura-3 pump is being rectified at no cost, workover options are being evaluated at Cascadura-4, and compression at Cascadura should stabilise deliverability rather than chase aggressive growth there. Central Block remains upside, not existential risk but CR-3 should tell us most of what we need to know for the rest of 2026. I’d rather see TXP survive, de-lever and rebuild by growing Central Block sensibly than chase higher-risk growth elsewhere or be forced into a distressed outcome.

data.author: ab76
data.content: For a reminded about why there’s a need for a compressor, see the August 2026 presentation - https://youtube.com/watch?v=HNNcGlKK1BY - at 23:13, 29:16 and 37:48. Note that Central Block, which has the same formation as Cascudura, has a compressor. Touchstone had hoped they could do without one for the first couple of years at Cascudura, but the declines persuaded them otherwise. The compressor will provide pressure stability that will both boost production and stability. As Paul acknowledged recently, the full effect won’t be known until it’s switched on, but it’s unlikely to be a $6.7 million gimmick.

data.author: John2727
data.content: The TRIN comparison doesn’t really hold. Cas hasn’t been suffering from terminal reservoir collapse or extreme wellhead pressure constraints in the way TRIN’s legacy onshore system was. The issue has been system back-pressure and export constraints, not wells “running out of gas.” TXP’s setup is also fundamentally different: dedicated infrastructure, controlled inflows, and compression added proactively rather than as a last-ditch optimisation on a dying asset. The rationale for the new compressor comes directly from observed results at Central Block, where compression materially stabilised output across multiple producing wells. No one is suggesting compression reverses reservoir decline. The objective is to reduce back-pressure, improve drawdown, slow pressure-driven decline and stabilise the base

data.author: sirmark
data.content: Here's the contents Trinidad and Tobago’s energy sector is positioning for modest recovery in 2026, supported by near-term production projects and new momentum around accessing Venezuela’s offshore gas reserves. While domestic output remains below past highs, operators are moving ahead with developments that could stabilise supply and extend the life of key infrastructure. bpTT is set to bring its Cypre field online in 2024, with the Mento project expected to follow by 2026. Shell’s Manatee field, a larger offshore development, is targeting first gas in 2027. These timelines reflect a longer build-out cycle, but the government has signalled progress in streamlining approvals to speed up execution. Touchstone Exploration is also expanding onshore activity, with current drilling focused on tying in to midstream infrastructure. With large undeveloped gas reserves just across the maritime border, including the Dragon and Manakin–Cocuina fields, Venezuela offers a clear supply-side opportunity. These fields are close enough to be tied into Trinidad and Tobago’s existing processing and LNG facilities with relatively limited new investment. Touchstone’s leadership has also expressed interest in opportunities tied to Venezuela, noting the size of the reserves and the regional infrastructure advantages. While smaller players face higher entry barriers, alignment between state and corporate interests could open access over time. Touchstone Exploration Inc (LON:TXP) is a Canadian-based, international upstream oil and gas company currently active in the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago. Primera Oil and Gas is the Trinidadian subsidiary of Touchstone.

data.author: John2727
data.content: G, I think you’re conflating three different things, which is exactly why these threads go in circles. Operating cash vs free cash flow You’re absolutely right that TXP has been FCF-negative during a heavy capex phase. That’s not controversial, and it’s been openly stated by management. But that’s a capital allocation choice, not a sign the underlying business can’t generate cash. TXP can cover debt service and opex from operations, and still be FCF-negative if it chooses to reinvest heavily. Those are not mutually exclusive. Debt service vs balance sheet optics. The point I made (and keep making) is narrower than the argument you’re rebutting. I’m not saying TXP is “financially strong” in a balance-sheet sense today. I am saying existing production covers debt servicing and running costs. That matters, because it means CR-3 is about upside and inflection, not insolvency. A poor CR-3 outcome does not automatically create a “zombie company” That distinction gets lost when everything is framed as binary success/failure. The share price doesn’t reflect “can the company pay its bills” It reflects, dilution risk, execution fatigue, credibility scars from past guidance and capital intensity vs timing. All fair points but they’re market psychology, not proof the operating base is broken. As for covenant waivers again, not unusual in a scale-up phase following a major acquisition. They’re uncomfortable, but not the same as being unable to service debt. But we’re not cash-dead, and CR-3 does not determine whether the lights stay on. CR-3 determines pricing uplift, speed of deleveraging and whether growth is self-funded or diluted. That’s the distinction I was making and not claiming everything is rosy. Happy to debate numbers, but it helps if we’re debating the same question.

data.author: G_G_G
data.content: no it's conjobbaay just talking **** again. i mean venezuela now, what a ****. john27, you of all people should be the last person talking about how we can cover this and that through cashflow. the number of times discord members have shouted down people with such numbers is quite ridiculous. and none of them have come remotely close to the appalling figures that have ended up being reported. if we were so financially sound, we wouldn't be sitting in single digits after drilling such a promising well. simple as that. as for the numbers you are quoting, there's a big difference between operating income and how much cash we're generating. here's your reality check: overview: based on the most recent rns filings (up to q3 2025, released in november 2025), touchstone exploration is currently in a "heavy investment" phase. while production is scaling up, free cash flow remains negative because capital expenditures (drilling and acquisitions) are currently outstripping the cash generated from operations. note on cash generation: the company uses "funds flow from operations" as its primary cash metric. free cash flow (fcf) here is estimated by subtracting capital expenditures from funds flow. as you can see, the fcf has been increasingly negative over the past 12 months as they ramp up drilling at cascadura. recent quarter analysis: q3 2025 the most recent quarter shows a company under temporary financial pressure but with growing asset scale: - net debt surge: debt climbed to $77.75 million, largely due to a $12.5 million convertible debenture and the earlier $30 million acquisition of the "central block." - production: averaged 5,141 boe/d. while this is an increase over q2, the "funds flow" dropped to just $0.74m due to higher financing costs (interest on that new debt) and higher taxes. - the "waiver": crucially, touchstone had to obtain a financial covenant waiver from its lender for the end of 2025, suggesting they are operating very close to their debt limits. next 12 months: outlook for 2026 - the health of the company over the next 12 months depends entirely on converting recent drilling into consistent cash: - revenue growth: analysts project revenue growth of ~49% as new wells like cascadura-5 and carapal ridge-3 (results announced jan 2026) contribute to the full-year total. - cash inflection: the company expects to generate roughly $22 million in funds flow for the full year 2025/2026. if they keep capital spending around the $23m mark (as budgeted), they will be roughly cash-flow neutral or slightly negative until the next major production step-change. - debt reduction: management’s goal is to bring net debt back down toward $30 million by the end of 2025/early 2026, though this relies on no further major acquisition spending. summary: touchstone is "asset rich but cash tight." they have successfully grown production, but the cost of that growth has pushed debt to a peak. they need a smooth, high-volume product

data.author: John2727
data.content: a few people still seem confused about cash flow and debt, so here it is in simple, real-world terms. we’re already covering debt comfortably today, before cr-3 pricing uplift. current position central block gas: 18–19 mmscf/d gross 13–14 mmscf/d net us$14–15m p.a. gas revenue this alone covers annual debt payments (us$5–6m) add cas-1 & cas-2 gas 6–7 mmscf/d gross 4.5–5 mmscf/d net us$5m p.a. additional gas revenue add cas-5 oil (small but real): modest volumes, but still ≈ us$3–4m p.a. net cash so before cr-3 pricing uplift, group operating cash is roughly: us$22–24m per year so……. debt is covered opex is covered txp is already cash-generative cr-3 is not about survival like some are suggesting. what changes once central block moves above 22 mmscf/d? meaning cr3 only needs to settle at 4 mmscf/d gas pricing steps up from us$3.0/mcf to us$3.6/mcf (after all costs) at 24 mmscf/d cb, that pricing uplift alone adds roughly us$3.7m per year and drops straight to cash debt is already covered today with cas production alone and cas-1, cas-2 and cas-5 mean txp is already running a surplus cr-3 + higher pricing turns that surplus into meaningful free cash flow. equity raises are **** and could have been done better but are about speed and scale, not keeping the lights on. that’s the bit that often gets missed. happy to be corrected but even with a +- 10% we’re looking in good shape to get straight into cr4 once cr3 is hooked up. (based on last financial statement)

data.thread_title: If (WHEN!) Both VAT recovery and gas uplift occur

data.author: Sturm
data.content: Where Millstone is wrong...,  implicitly asserting this: “Without success at Cas-4, Cas-5 and CR-3, the debt is not serviceable.” That is not supported by the numbers. Why that’s incorrect: Even excluding Cas-4 / Cas-5 / CR-3 success, Touchstone still has: Existing producing cash flow Cascadura + Central Block Enough to cover interest ~4–5× Structural tailwinds not tied to wells 2027 gas price uplift VAT recoveries (cash / bonds) Manageable debt profile No immediate principal cliff Issue is covenants and leverage, not liquidity collapse That means: Debt is serviceable But not comfortable aAnd not deleveraging meaningfully VAT recovery and gas price uplift are exogenous to Cas-4 / Cas-5 / CR-3. They change the balance sheet without drilling success. What happens to Millstones argument if any of the events happens: VAT or Gas price uplift? Debt becomes clearly serviceable Covenant pressure eases Dilution risk reduces materially ❌ Millstone’s claim that drilling success is required is weakened ❌ Debt stress is no longer binary 👉 VAT alone does not make Touchstone comfortable — but it breaks the “unserviceable” claim.

Central volumes contributed approximately 2,217 boe/d during the third quarter. ·      Petroleum and Natural Gas Sales: Totaled $12.70 million, a 4 percent decrease from $13.25 million recorded in the comparative prior year quarter. -     Crude oil sales: $5.84 million from average production of 1,051 bbls/d at an average realized price of $60.30 per barrel. -     NGL sales: $1.34 million from average production volumes of 436 bbls/d at an average realized price of $33.41 per barrel. -     Natural gas sales: $5.52 million from average production of 21.9 MMcf/d (3,654 boe/d) at an average realized price of $2.74 per Mcf. ·      Operating Netback: Generated $5.86 million in operating netback, a 21 percent decrease from the third quarter of 2024, primarily due to decreased petroleum and natural gas sales and related royalties and increased natural gas operating expenses. ·      Funds Flow from Operations: Declined to $0.74 million from $3.02 million in the prior year equivalent quarter, largely driven by lower operating netbacks, higher cash finance expenses, and increased current income taxes, partially offset by lower transaction costs. ·      Net Loss: Recorded a net loss of $2.06 million ($0.01 per share) compared to net earnings of $1.85 million ($0.01 per share) in the third quarter of 2024. data.author: rossannan
data.content: G_G_G Not a stretch.  The chances of a non-commercial CR-3 are significant.  At that point everything stops and you are probably in strategic review territory at best.  Good luck with that.  A marginally commercial CR-3 would still leave TXP a steep hill to climb. Only a very robust performance from CR-3 is going to re-establish a growth trajectory here.  I think you need to entirely tune out the fanboy narrative around CR-3 (remember how wrong they got Cas-5) and look again at the balance of risk and reward.  It looks like a coin toss to me, so I just don’t see the attraction.  It’s speculation, not investment. I think this could be a good year for O&G but there are better propositions out there.

data.author: ab76
data.content: More from Paul in this article - https://trinidadexpress.com/business/local/touchstone-ceo-sees-opportunity-in-venezuela/article_4b4f2e99-59f9-4360-b17c-fb97a21a70c6.html : “We’ve downsized a little bit in the last year and that is a result of some of the wells not performing as well as we originally thought, so we had to make those adjustments. But as we start to ramp up here with the new acquisition we’ve done, and as we do more drilling, we use more local content—which is also a tricky term in Trinidad, because local content can be ‘local content’ and ‘local local content’ right down to the neighbourhoods we operate in. As we move out of an area and into another, there is a perception that some of the jobs are lost, but generally, they get picked up wherever we’re moving to.” Baay said one of the major recent developments at the company has been the completed drilling of the Central Block, about which he said he was excited, despite the slow start; he predicted a busy 2026.

data.author: ab76
data.content: The relevant bit from the article sirmark referred to is: Touchstone Exploration’s Paul Baay agreed that the sector is in a good place, as he explained that the ministry’s acceleration of approvals had brought up the date of potential returns from the company’s recent drilling of onshore wells at Central Block. “I think the key thing there is, because we’re onshore, some of our projects can get turned around quicker, like we can physically drill a well and get it in production much quicker than some of these big offshore ones. So the new Government is recognising that and helped us with approvals, like certificates for environmental compliance,” Baay said. “We drilled the first well. We want to drill a second well, really quickly. That process, you know, used to be a nine-month process, and it’s been shrunk down. Now it looks like it’s going to be literally a couple of weeks, maybe a month.” Baay added that the company could see some returns from that activity by the end of February. “We drilled the first well in December at the central block, and that’s going to come on at the end of February. So you know that’s like, we’re not talking quarters here. We’re talking months and weeks from when we can drill a well to when we get it on production,” he said. Baay said, “Those are the kind of reaction times that I think the new Government is recognising and putting in place the necessary things that we see. So from our point of view, that saves us money and saves us time. From the Government’s point of view, that gets molecules on quicker for all of those suppliers that need them.” The full article is available at https://guardian.co.tt/business/energy-sector-optimistic-about-2026-6.2.2501152.bff3b02b0a

data.author: aligator
data.content: Well completion and flow testing are ongoing, with tie-in to the Central Block gas processing facility expected to be achieved by end March.  In the O&G industry, what happens during such periods is that those physically undertaking the  work/assessment become pregnant with inside knowledge and are aware that there are many outsiders willing to "obtain" such information for investment purposes, invariably for reward.  It is more than possible that this little sp recovery is down to the leak of such information, which suggests that CR-3 is looking good.  However, how many times over the past 2-3 years have we been in this situation, only to be told that wells have not either not met expectations or encountered problems or some other issue? That said, I am keeping my fingers crossed on this because, as I commented previously, success with CR-3 could see the sp tick up to ca 15p (which would reflect a 50% increase) but more bad news will crater the sp, possibly to below 5p.

data.author: Sturm
data.content: Ross... The question isn’t who’s felt luckiest over the last 20 months; it’s whether the current price reflects the forward risk/reward. Repeating “9p is about right” and invoking a vague risk of “going to zero” doesn’t make the case unless you explain how that happens — mechanically and financially. I’m not dismissing risk; I’m explicitly modelling it. If CR-3 fails, downside is limited to where we are now. If it lands even mid-case, the valuation moves materially. That asymmetry is the whole point. Calling that “going to zero risk” without showing a credible path to insolvency is assertion, not argument. Time will tell — but time tends to reward those who quantify probabilities, not those who rely on being “lucky”. If you have better things to do than explain your argument, that’s fine — but then don’t expect “trust me, I’ve been lucky” to carry any weight.

data.author: Sturm
data.content: Ross.... That’s a mischaracterisation, but exactly what anyone could expect from you. How's it going with answering the 14+ questions you've been asked to prove your POV? CR-3 isn’t about “short-term success”; it’s about re-rating optionality. The company can service debt and operate without CR-3 — what CR-3 changes is how quickly and how decisively the balance sheet and equity narrative improve. Calling it a “coin toss” ignores the asymmetry. A failed well caps downside near today’s valuation; a commercially successful well materially shifts cash flow, probabilities, and pricing assumptions — as we’ve just shown numerically. That’s not a gamble, it’s a skewed payoff. Saying “9p is about right” simply restates the current price, not a valuation. The market isn’t declaring CR-3 worthless; it’s withholding value until data arrives. That’s uncertainty pricing, not proof the reward is inadequate. If CR-3 lands anywhere near the mid-case, the maths moves quickly. If it doesn’t, value drops back to where it is now. That’s exactly why this isn’t a binary survival bet — it’s a de-risking catalyst with disproportionate upside.

data.author: ab76
data.content: Touchstone's short term success is dependant upon a good CR3 result. Expectations are being managed, but the prediction last year (see for example the August 2025 presentation) was it would produce 10 million per day and more recently Touchstone has indicated that if four wells are added to Central Block this year production from that block alone could more than double (with the increase attracting a much higher price than existing production). If that happens, and we'll have a better idea once we get the CR3 results, the disasters of 2025 will be well behind us. There's also plenty of gas still to extract from Cascudura, but it makes sense to leave it to 2027 when much higher prices will apply once the existing contract expires. A bonus this year will be if there's a deep oil farm out and some drilling. That's difficult to predict, but after years of decline there's increasing interest in Trinidad (evidenced amongst other things by Exxon's return last August) perhaps in part because of the deep oil discoveries in Guyana etc and the new government's red-tape cutting should help too. Add in the boost from the compressor in May/June and a VAT refund, and it may well be a very good year. Nothing's guaranteed though.

data.author: ab76
data.content: Trinidad’s energy sector, which has suffered a significant decline over the past decade, still has plenty of life left in it. It’s not only Touchstone that’s been exploring for and finding significant new resources, but the large independents have been buying up assets (Perenco has invested billions over the past couple of years) and the majors have been busy. Exxon returned last August, Shell and BP never left, and Chevron and Total are interested. There’s even an increasing prospect that Trinidad’s refinery will reopen later this year (see https://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/After-Years-Offline-Trinidad-Looks-to-Indian-Oil-to-Restart-Refining.amp.html). Oil production is rising again and some major gas projects will soon come on line. Energy still makes up about half the economy and, although there are various ways to further improve the fiscal system, it’s not a bad place to do business (Touchstone, like other producers, has no transportation costs and is paid monthly in US dollars). I’m much more comfortable investing in Trinidad than, say, in a company producing oil in the jungles of Peru. The AIM has its flaws, but plenty of decent companies, including Touchstone, are listed on it. It’s far from untouchable and Warren Buffett, through CalEnergy, had a partnership with Parkmead Group (an AIM company).

data.author: rossannan
data.content: Sturm/G_G_G Buffett wouldn’t go anywhere near AIM though.  On AIM, if there even is FCF in the first place, predicting it involves a great deal of conjecture.  Working from historical FCF allows you to draw a more reliable trajectory while also assessing what was delivered at each stage against what was then expected. When significant positive change is promised or even just a possibility, it is tempting to load up in anticipation.  More often than not though you are better on the sidelines - in the event of disappointment you are well out while if significant positive change is actually delivered you will understand its significance and be able to get in ahead of those who don’t (likely buying the shares of the inevitable sellers into the news).

data.content: Dunder, it was the value of the RNS / CR3 alone (not counting Karamat etc.). data.author: Sturm
data.content: Dunder, On stepped pricing that improves with volume and a conservative P/E of 3, CR-3 contributes ~$50m probability-weighted, or ~12p per TXP share, before any credit for follow-ons, VAT, or broader rerating, on these assumptions: Net gas rates to TXP: 5 / 10 / 15 / 20 mmcf/d Stepped realised gas prices (blended): 5 mmcf → $4.50/mcf 10 mmcf → $5.00/mcf 15 mmcf → $5.50/mcf 20 mmcf → $6.00/mcf NGL yield: ~5% of boe, NGL netback $40/bbl Forward multiple: P/E = 3 Shares outstanding: ~325m FX: $1 = £0.78 Probabilities: 5 mmcf: 25% 10 mmcf: 30% 15 mmcf: 20% 20 mmcf: 5% Failure: 20% Market cap on success (per tier) 5 mmcf → ~$26m 10 mmcf → ~$58m 15 mmcf → ~$96m 20 mmcf → ~$139m Probability-weighted market cap 0.25 × 26 = $6.6m 0.30 × 58 = $17.5m 0.20 × 96 = $19.2m 0.05 × 139 = $6.9m Failure = $0 ➡ Total ≈ $50m probability-weighted Per-share value $50m ÷ 325m shares ≈ $0.155/share Converted to GBP ≈ ~12.0p per share

data.author: John2727
data.content: There’s no argument that earlier expectations were optimistic. But today TXP is a very different company. Cascadura, Central Block and legacy production are all real, producing and cash-positive, and together they cover debt service - albeit without much slack. That’s exactly why management has prioritised stability over growth at this time. Central Block is already a meaningful cash contributor: while it represents roughly 40–45% of volumes, its lower operating costs mean it contributes a higher share of operating cash flow. With the main pipeline runs now complete and only final tie-ins and sign-off remaining, Central Block is well positioned to be the most efficient area for near-term growth. Some recent declines are operational rather than structural. The manufacturing fault on the Cascadura-3 pump is being rectified at no cost, workover options are being evaluated at Cascadura-4, and compression at Cascadura should stabilise deliverability rather than chase aggressive growth there. Central Block remains upside, not existential risk but CR-3 should tell us most of what we need to know for the rest of 2026. I’d rather see TXP survive, de-lever and rebuild by growing Central Block sensibly than chase higher-risk growth elsewhere or be forced into a distressed outcome.

data.author: ab76
data.content: For a reminded about why there’s a need for a compressor, see the August 2026 presentation - https://youtube.com/watch?v=HNNcGlKK1BY - at 23:13, 29:16 and 37:48. Note that Central Block, which has the same formation as Cascudura, has a compressor. Touchstone had hoped they could do without one for the first couple of years at Cascudura, but the declines persuaded them otherwise. The compressor will provide pressure stability that will both boost production and stability. As Paul acknowledged recently, the full effect won’t be known until it’s switched on, but it’s unlikely to be a $6.7 million gimmick.

data.author: John2727
data.content: The TRIN comparison doesn’t really hold. Cas hasn’t been suffering from terminal reservoir collapse or extreme wellhead pressure constraints in the way TRIN’s legacy onshore system was. The issue has been system back-pressure and export constraints, not wells “running out of gas.” TXP’s setup is also fundamentally different: dedicated infrastructure, controlled inflows, and compression added proactively rather than as a last-ditch optimisation on a dying asset. The rationale for the new compressor comes directly from observed results at Central Block, where compression materially stabilised output across multiple producing wells. No one is suggesting compression reverses reservoir decline. The objective is to reduce back-pressure, improve drawdown, slow pressure-driven decline and stabilise the base

data.author: sirmark
data.content: Here's the contents Trinidad and Tobago’s energy sector is positioning for modest recovery in 2026, supported by near-term production projects and new momentum around accessing Venezuela’s offshore gas reserves. While domestic output remains below past highs, operators are moving ahead with developments that could stabilise supply and extend the life of key infrastructure. bpTT is set to bring its Cypre field online in 2024, with the Mento project expected to follow by 2026. Shell’s Manatee field, a larger offshore development, is targeting first gas in 2027. These timelines reflect a longer build-out cycle, but the government has signalled progress in streamlining approvals to speed up execution. Touchstone Exploration is also expanding onshore activity, with current drilling focused on tying in to midstream infrastructure. With large undeveloped gas reserves just across the maritime border, including the Dragon and Manakin–Cocuina fields, Venezuela offers a clear supply-side opportunity. These fields are close enough to be tied into Trinidad and Tobago’s existing processing and LNG facilities with relatively limited new investment. Touchstone’s leadership has also expressed interest in opportunities tied to Venezuela, noting the size of the reserves and the regional infrastructure advantages. While smaller players face higher entry barriers, alignment between state and corporate interests could open access over time. Touchstone Exploration Inc (LON:TXP) is a Canadian-based, international upstream oil and gas company currently active in the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago. Primera Oil and Gas is the Trinidadian subsidiary of Touchstone.

data.author: John2727
data.content: G, I think you’re conflating three different things, which is exactly why these threads go in circles. Operating cash vs free cash flow You’re absolutely right that TXP has been FCF-negative during a heavy capex phase. That’s not controversial, and it’s been openly stated by management. But that’s a capital allocation choice, not a sign the underlying business can’t generate cash. TXP can cover debt service and opex from operations, and still be FCF-negative if it chooses to reinvest heavily. Those are not mutually exclusive. Debt service vs balance sheet optics. The point I made (and keep making) is narrower than the argument you’re rebutting. I’m not saying TXP is “financially strong” in a balance-sheet sense today. I am saying existing production covers debt servicing and running costs. That matters, because it means CR-3 is about upside and inflection, not insolvency. A poor CR-3 outcome does not automatically create a “zombie company” That distinction gets lost when everything is framed as binary success/failure. The share price doesn’t reflect “can the company pay its bills” It reflects, dilution risk, execution fatigue, credibility scars from past guidance and capital intensity vs timing. All fair points but they’re market psychology, not proof the operating base is broken. As for covenant waivers again, not unusual in a scale-up phase following a major acquisition. They’re uncomfortable, but not the same as being unable to service debt. But we’re not cash-dead, and CR-3 does not determine whether the lights stay on. CR-3 determines pricing uplift, speed of deleveraging and whether growth is self-funded or diluted. That’s the distinction I was making and not claiming everything is rosy. Happy to debate numbers, but it helps if we’re debating the same question.

data.author: G_G_G
data.content: no it's conjobbaay just talking **** again. i mean venezuela now, what a ****. john27, you of all people should be the last person talking about how we can cover this and that through cashflow. the number of times discord members have shouted down people with such numbers is quite ridiculous. and none of them have come remotely close to the appalling figures that have ended up being reported. if we were so financially sound, we wouldn't be sitting in single digits after drilling such a promising well. simple as that. as for the numbers you are quoting, there's a big difference between operating income and how much cash we're generating. here's your reality check: overview: based on the most recent rns filings (up to q3 2025, released in november 2025), touchstone exploration is currently in a "heavy investment" phase. while production is scaling up, free cash flow remains negative because capital expenditures (drilling and acquisitions) are currently outstripping the cash generated from operations. note on cash generation: the company uses "funds flow from operations" as its primary cash metric. free cash flow (fcf) here is estimated by subtracting capital expenditures from funds flow. as you can see, the fcf has been increasingly negative over the past 12 months as they ramp up drilling at cascadura. recent quarter analysis: q3 2025 the most recent quarter shows a company under temporary financial pressure but with growing asset scale: - net debt surge: debt climbed to $77.75 million, largely due to a $12.5 million convertible debenture and the earlier $30 million acquisition of the "central block." - production: averaged 5,141 boe/d. while this is an increase over q2, the "funds flow" dropped to just $0.74m due to higher financing costs (interest on that new debt) and higher taxes. - the "waiver": crucially, touchstone had to obtain a financial covenant waiver from its lender for the end of 2025, suggesting they are operating very close to their debt limits. next 12 months: outlook for 2026 - the health of the company over the next 12 months depends entirely on converting recent drilling into consistent cash: - revenue growth: analysts project revenue growth of ~49% as new wells like cascadura-5 and carapal ridge-3 (results announced jan 2026) contribute to the full-year total. - cash inflection: the company expects to generate roughly $22 million in funds flow for the full year 2025/2026. if they keep capital spending around the $23m mark (as budgeted), they will be roughly cash-flow neutral or slightly negative until the next major production step-change. - debt reduction: management’s goal is to bring net debt back down toward $30 million by the end of 2025/early 2026, though this relies on no further major acquisition spending. summary: touchstone is "asset rich but cash tight." they have successfully grown production, but the cost of that growth has pushed debt to a peak. they need a smooth, high-volume product

data.author: John2727
data.content: a few people still seem confused about cash flow and debt, so here it is in simple, real-world terms. we’re already covering debt comfortably today, before cr-3 pricing uplift. current position central block gas: 18–19 mmscf/d gross 13–14 mmscf/d net us$14–15m p.a. gas revenue this alone covers annual debt payments (us$5–6m) add cas-1 & cas-2 gas 6–7 mmscf/d gross 4.5–5 mmscf/d net us$5m p.a. additional gas revenue add cas-5 oil (small but real): modest volumes, but still ≈ us$3–4m p.a. net cash so before cr-3 pricing uplift, group operating cash is roughly: us$22–24m per year so……. debt is covered opex is covered txp is already cash-generative cr-3 is not about survival like some are suggesting. what changes once central block moves above 22 mmscf/d? meaning cr3 only needs to settle at 4 mmscf/d gas pricing steps up from us$3.0/mcf to us$3.6/mcf (after all costs) at 24 mmscf/d cb, that pricing uplift alone adds roughly us$3.7m per year and drops straight to cash debt is already covered today with cas production alone and cas-1, cas-2 and cas-5 mean txp is already running a surplus cr-3 + higher pricing turns that surplus into meaningful free cash flow. equity raises are **** and could have been done better but are about speed and scale, not keeping the lights on. that’s the bit that often gets missed. happy to be corrected but even with a +- 10% we’re looking in good shape to get straight into cr4 once cr3 is hooked up. (based on last financial statement)

data.content: How abour answering these questions: 1) “What do you mean by ‘not serviceable’ — inability to pay interest, or just lack of comfort?” 2) “Which year do you believe Touchstone actually defaults if none of these wells succeed?” 3) “Why do you exclude VAT recovery when assessing debt service, given it directly reduces net debt?” 4) “At what level of VAT recovery would your debt-stress thesis no longer hold?” 5) “Do you assume Trinidad gas prices stay flat indefinitely — and if so, why?” 6) “How much incremental cash flow would a $1/mcf uplift generate — and why doesn’t that change debt serviceability?” 7) “Are you arguing Touchstone cannot survive, or that it cannot grow without new wells?” 8) “Do you accept that debt can be serviced but deleveraging requires success?” 9) “Why would lenders force a default when interest is covered and leverage improves via VAT or pricing?” 10) “What covenant specifically is breached after VAT recovery or price uplift?” 11) “Is there any non-drilling scenario under which you believe debt is serviceable?” 12) “Are Cas-4, Cas-5 and CR-3 equally necessary, or would success at just one suffice?” 13) “What specific cash shortfall causes insolvency after interest, VAT recovery, and gas price uplift — and in which year?”

data.thread_title: If (WHEN!) Both VAT recovery and gas uplift occur

data.author: Sturm
data.content: Where Millstone is wrong...,  implicitly asserting this: “Without success at Cas-4, Cas-5 and CR-3, the debt is not serviceable.” That is not supported by the numbers. Why that’s incorrect: Even excluding Cas-4 / Cas-5 / CR-3 success, Touchstone still has: Existing producing cash flow Cascadura + Central Block Enough to cover interest ~4–5× Structural tailwinds not tied to wells 2027 gas price uplift VAT recoveries (cash / bonds) Manageable debt profile No immediate principal cliff Issue is covenants and leverage, not liquidity collapse That means: Debt is serviceable But not comfortable aAnd not deleveraging meaningfully VAT recovery and gas price uplift are exogenous to Cas-4 / Cas-5 / CR-3. They change the balance sheet without drilling success. What happens to Millstones argument if any of the events happens: VAT or Gas price uplift? Debt becomes clearly serviceable Covenant pressure eases Dilution risk reduces materially ❌ Millstone’s claim that drilling success is required is weakened ❌ Debt stress is no longer binary 👉 VAT alone does not make Touchstone comfortable — but it breaks the “unserviceable” claim.

data.content: G_G_G Not a stretch.  The chances of a non-commercial CR-3 are significant.  At that point everything stops and you are probably in strategic review territory at best.  Good luck with that.  A marginally commercial CR-3 would still leave TXP a steep hill to climb. Only a very robust performance from CR-3 is going to re-establish a growth trajectory here.  I think you need to entirely tune out the fanboy narrative around CR-3 (remember how wrong they got Cas-5) and look again at the balance of risk and reward. data.author: ab76
data.content: More from Paul in this article - https://trinidadexpress.com/business/local/touchstone-ceo-sees-opportunity-in-venezuela/article_4b4f2e99-59f9-4360-b17c-fb97a21a70c6.html : “We’ve downsized a little bit in the last year and that is a result of some of the wells not performing as well as we originally thought, so we had to make those adjustments. But as we start to ramp up here with the new acquisition we’ve done, and as we do more drilling, we use more local content—which is also a tricky term in Trinidad, because local content can be ‘local content’ and ‘local local content’ right down to the neighbourhoods we operate in. As we move out of an area and into another, there is a perception that some of the jobs are lost, but generally, they get picked up wherever we’re moving to.” Baay said one of the major recent developments at the company has been the completed drilling of the Central Block, about which he said he was excited, despite the slow start; he predicted a busy 2026.

data.author: ab76
data.content: The relevant bit from the article sirmark referred to is: Touchstone Exploration’s Paul Baay agreed that the sector is in a good place, as he explained that the ministry’s acceleration of approvals had brought up the date of potential returns from the company’s recent drilling of onshore wells at Central Block. “I think the key thing there is, because we’re onshore, some of our projects can get turned around quicker, like we can physically drill a well and get it in production much quicker than some of these big offshore ones. So the new Government is recognising that and helped us with approvals, like certificates for environmental compliance,” Baay said. “We drilled the first well. We want to drill a second well, really quickly. That process, you know, used to be a nine-month process, and it’s been shrunk down. Now it looks like it’s going to be literally a couple of weeks, maybe a month.” Baay added that the company could see some returns from that activity by the end of February. “We drilled the first well in December at the central block, and that’s going to come on at the end of February. So you know that’s like, we’re not talking quarters here. We’re talking months and weeks from when we can drill a well to when we get it on production,” he said. Baay said, “Those are the kind of reaction times that I think the new Government is recognising and putting in place the necessary things that we see. So from our point of view, that saves us money and saves us time. From the Government’s point of view, that gets molecules on quicker for all of those suppliers that need them.” The full article is available at https://guardian.co.tt/business/energy-sector-optimistic-about-2026-6.2.2501152.bff3b02b0a

data.author: aligator
data.content: Well completion and flow testing are ongoing, with tie-in to the Central Block gas processing facility expected to be achieved by end March.  In the O&G industry, what happens during such periods is that those physically undertaking the  work/assessment become pregnant with inside knowledge and are aware that there are many outsiders willing to "obtain" such information for investment purposes, invariably for reward.  It is more than possible that this little sp recovery is down to the leak of such information, which suggests that CR-3 is looking good.  However, how many times over the past 2-3 years have we been in this situation, only to be told that wells have not either not met expectations or encountered problems or some other issue? That said, I am keeping my fingers crossed on this because, as I commented previously, success with CR-3 could see the sp tick up to ca 15p (which would reflect a 50% increase) but more bad news will crater the sp, possibly to below 5p.

data.author: Sturm
data.content: Ross... #PTAL has made plenty of serious mistakes — on a par with TXP, frankly. Several were genuinely existential. Off the top of my head: Paying dividends prematurely. Failing to hedge massive oil volumes while carrying heavy debt, despite explicit warnings. That one is hard to excuse. Nearly killed the company and diluted shareholders massively. The ONP oil sales terms — absurd. A structure that leaves risk on your books after the oil is supposedly “sold”. Handing out an enormous number of investor warrants. A “substantially oversubscribed” raise — to quote Manolo — is not a success when it results in dilution far beyond what was required. Issuing a high-cost bond that was roughly four times larger than needed, supposedly to fund acquisitions. No acquisitions followed. They didn’t even buy back the investor warrants (around 300m, IIRC). Promising to drill Block 107 at IPO, then repeatedly failing to deliver. Year after year of “next year, Rodney”. And as for the TRIN acquisition — I still struggle to see how anyone thought that was smart for TXP. No synergy, just added complexity layered onto the same cost base. Central Block, by contrast, is a masterclass in synergy — exactly what a good acquisition should look like.

data.author: Sturm
data.content: Ross... The question isn’t who’s felt luckiest over the last 20 months; it’s whether the current price reflects the forward risk/reward. Repeating “9p is about right” and invoking a vague risk of “going to zero” doesn’t make the case unless you explain how that happens — mechanically and financially. I’m not dismissing risk; I’m explicitly modelling it. If CR-3 fails, downside is limited to where we are now. If it lands even mid-case, the valuation moves materially. That asymmetry is the whole point. Calling that “going to zero risk” without showing a credible path to insolvency is assertion, not argument. Time will tell — but time tends to reward those who quantify probabilities, not those who rely on being “lucky”. If you have better things to do than explain your argument, that’s fine — but then don’t expect “trust me, I’ve been lucky” to carry any weight.
data.thread_title: RE: February is going to be a winner

data.author: Sturm
data.content: Ross.... That’s a mischaracterisation, but exactly what anyone could expect from you. How's it going with answering the 14+ questions you've been asked to prove your POV? CR-3 isn’t about “short-term success”; it’s about re-rating optionality. The company can service debt and operate without CR-3 — what CR-3 changes is how quickly and how decisively the balance sheet and equity narrative improve. Calling it a “coin toss” ignores the asymmetry. A failed well caps downside near today’s valuation; a commercially successful well materially shifts cash flow, probabilities, and pricing assumptions — as we’ve just shown numerically. That’s not a gamble, it’s a skewed payoff. Saying “9p is about right” simply restates the current price, not a valuation. The market isn’t declaring CR-3 worthless; it’s withholding value until data arrives. That’s uncertainty pricing, not proof the reward is inadequate. If CR-3 lands anywhere near the mid-case, the maths moves quickly. If it doesn’t, value drops back to where it is now. That’s exactly why this isn’t a binary survival bet — it’s a de-risking catalyst with disproportionate upside.
data.thread_title: RE: RE: February is going to be a stinker !!!!

What you have here has been fairly described by others as a coin toss: unattractive either as an investment or a gamble.  The reward does not outweigh the risk: 9p is about right - the market gets it even if Discord doesn’t.

data.author: ab76
data.content: Touchstone's short term success is dependant upon a good CR3 result. Expectations are being managed, but the prediction last year (see for example the August 2025 presentation) was it would produce 10 million per day and more recently Touchstone has indicated that if four wells are added to Central Block this year production from that block alone could more than double (with the increase attracting a much higher price than existing production). If that happens, and we'll have a better idea once we get the CR3 results, the disasters of 2025 will be well behind us. There's also plenty of gas still to extract from Cascudura, but it makes sense to leave it to 2027 when much higher prices will apply once the existing contract expires. A bonus this year will be if there's a deep oil farm out and some drilling. That's difficult to predict, but after years of decline there's increasing interest in Trinidad (evidenced amongst other things by Exxon's return last August) perhaps in part because of the deep oil discoveries in Guyana etc and the new government's red-tape cutting should help too. Add in the boost from the compressor in May/June and a VAT refund, and it may well be a very good year. Nothing's guaranteed though.

That's difficult to predict, but after years of decline there's increasing interest in Trinidad (evidenced amongst other things by Exxon's return last August) perhaps in part because of the deep oil discoveries in Guyana etc and the new government's red-tape cutting should help too. Add in the boost from the compressor in May/June and a VAT refund, and it may well be a very good year. Nothing's guaranteed though.

data.author: rossannan
data.content: Ab76 That may be your perception of T&T O&G, but others are less sanguine, even with T&T under new management: https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2025/sep/19/trinidad-tobago-economy-oil-gas-fossil-fuels-climate-green-transition#:~:text=Today%2C%20with%20a%20population%20of ,the%20state%2Downed%20Petrotrin%20company. And I am sure that you are well aware of the longstanding “two-tier” approach of the T&T Government, which ensures that the oil and gas majors have very different experiences and outcomes than the independents. As for Parkmead, it was surely a footnote in an appendix that Buffet never read.  There is no comparison between the likes of Touchstone, Parkmead and the few serious O&G companies at the top end of AIM (such as Serica, CalEnergy’s new partner).

data.author: ab76
data.content: Trinidad’s energy sector, which has suffered a significant decline over the past decade, still has plenty of life left in it. It’s not only Touchstone that’s been exploring for and finding significant new resources, but the large independents have been buying up assets (Perenco has invested billions over the past couple of years) and the majors have been busy. Exxon returned last August, Shell and BP never left, and Chevron and Total are interested. There’s even an increasing prospect that Trinidad’s refinery will reopen later this year (see https://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/After-Years-Offline-Trinidad-Looks-to-Indian-Oil-to-Restart-Refining.amp.html). Oil production is rising again and some major gas projects will soon come on line. Energy still makes up about half the economy and, although there are various ways to further improve the fiscal system, it’s not a bad place to do business (Touchstone, like other producers, has no transportation costs and is paid monthly in US dollars). I’m much more comfortable investing in Trinidad than, say, in a company producing oil in the jungles of Peru. The AIM has its flaws, but plenty of decent companies, including Touchstone, are listed on it. It’s far from untouchable and Warren Buffett, through CalEnergy, had a partnership with Parkmead Group (an AIM company).

data.author: rossannan
data.content: Sturm/G_G_G Buffett wouldn’t go anywhere near AIM though.  On AIM, if there even is FCF in the first place, predicting it involves a great deal of conjecture.  Working from historical FCF allows you to draw a more reliable trajectory while also assessing what was delivered at each stage against what was then expected. When significant positive change is promised or even just a possibility, it is tempting to load up in anticipation.  More often than not though you are better on the sidelines - in the event of disappointment you are well out while if significant positive change is actually delivered you will understand its significance and be able to get in ahead of those who don’t (likely buying the shares of the inevitable sellers into the news).

data.author: Sturm
data.content: Dunder, it was the value of the RNS / CR3 alone (not counting Karamat etc.). Valuing CR3 at ~12p on a P/E of 3 is more or less equivalent to discounting the cash flows at roughly 25% IRR on a DCF basis (depending on the time frame). So that's pretty harsh :) So P/E of 3 /25% is my own go to for small cap - and totally subjective. The fun bit happens IF they at some point produce e.g. 60 mmcf across facilities at a fixed (higher) gas price - then I'd apply a P/E of mayby 6 - 8.

data.author: Sturm
data.content: Dunder, On stepped pricing that improves with volume and a conservative P/E of 3, CR-3 contributes ~$50m probability-weighted, or ~12p per TXP share, before any credit for follow-ons, VAT, or broader rerating, on these assumptions: Net gas rates to TXP: 5 / 10 / 15 / 20 mmcf/d Stepped realised gas prices (blended): 5 mmcf → $4.50/mcf 10 mmcf → $5.00/mcf 15 mmcf → $5.50/mcf 20 mmcf → $6.00/mcf NGL yield: ~5% of boe, NGL netback $40/bbl Forward multiple: P/E = 3 Shares outstanding: ~325m FX: $1 = £0.78 Probabilities: 5 mmcf: 25% 10 mmcf: 30% 15 mmcf: 20% 20 mmcf: 5% Failure: 20% Market cap on success (per tier) 5 mmcf → ~$26m 10 mmcf → ~$58m 15 mmcf → ~$96m 20 mmcf → ~$139m Probability-weighted market cap 0.25 × 26 = $6.6m 0.30 × 58 = $17.5m 0.20 × 96 = $19.2m 0.05 × 139 = $6.9m Failure = $0 ➡ Total ≈ $50m probability-weighted Per-share value $50m ÷ 325m shares ≈ $0.155/share Converted to GBP ≈ ~12.0p per share

data.author: John2727
data.content: There’s no argument that earlier expectations were optimistic. But today TXP is a very different company. Cascadura, Central Block and legacy production are all real, producing and cash-positive, and together they cover debt service - albeit without much slack. That’s exactly why management has prioritised stability over growth at this time. Central Block is already a meaningful cash contributor: while it represents roughly 40–45% of volumes, its lower operating costs mean it contributes a higher share of operating cash flow. With the main pipeline runs now complete and only final tie-ins and sign-off remaining, Central Block is well positioned to be the most efficient area for near-term growth. Some recent declines are operational rather than structural. The manufacturing fault on the Cascadura-3 pump is being rectified at no cost, workover options are being evaluated at Cascadura-4, and compression at Cascadura should stabilise deliverability rather than chase aggressive growth there. Central Block remains upside, not existential risk but CR-3 should tell us most of what we need to know for the rest of 2026. I’d rather see TXP survive, de-lever and rebuild by growing Central Block sensibly than chase higher-risk growth elsewhere or be forced into a distressed outcome.

data.author: ab76
data.content: For a reminded about why there’s a need for a compressor, see the August 2026 presentation - https://youtube.com/watch?v=HNNcGlKK1BY - at 23:13, 29:16 and 37:48. Note that Central Block, which has the same formation as Cascudura, has a compressor. Touchstone had hoped they could do without one for the first couple of years at Cascudura, but the declines persuaded them otherwise. The compressor will provide pressure stability that will both boost production and stability. As Paul acknowledged recently, the full effect won’t be known until it’s switched on, but it’s unlikely to be a $6.7 million gimmick.

data.author: John2727
data.content: The TRIN comparison doesn’t really hold. Cas hasn’t been suffering from terminal reservoir collapse or extreme wellhead pressure constraints in the way TRIN’s legacy onshore system was. The issue has been system back-pressure and export constraints, not wells “running out of gas.” TXP’s setup is also fundamentally different: dedicated infrastructure, controlled inflows, and compression added proactively rather than as a last-ditch optimisation on a dying asset. The rationale for the new compressor comes directly from observed results at Central Block, where compression materially stabilised output across multiple producing wells. No one is suggesting compression reverses reservoir decline. The objective is to reduce back-pressure, improve drawdown, slow pressure-driven decline and stabilise the base

data.author: sirmark
data.content: Here's the contents Trinidad and Tobago’s energy sector is positioning for modest recovery in 2026, supported by near-term production projects and new momentum around accessing Venezuela’s offshore gas reserves. While domestic output remains below past highs, operators are moving ahead with developments that could stabilise supply and extend the life of key infrastructure. bpTT is set to bring its Cypre field online in 2024, with the Mento project expected to follow by 2026. Shell’s Manatee field, a larger offshore development, is targeting first gas in 2027. These timelines reflect a longer build-out cycle, but the government has signalled progress in streamlining approvals to speed up execution. Touchstone Exploration is also expanding onshore activity, with current drilling focused on tying in to midstream infrastructure. With large undeveloped gas reserves just across the maritime border, including the Dragon and Manakin–Cocuina fields, Venezuela offers a clear supply-side opportunity. These fields are close enough to be tied into Trinidad and Tobago’s existing processing and LNG facilities with relatively limited new investment. Touchstone’s leadership has also expressed interest in opportunities tied to Venezuela, noting the size of the reserves and the regional infrastructure advantages. While smaller players face higher entry barriers, alignment between state and corporate interests could open access over time. Touchstone Exploration Inc (LON:TXP) is a Canadian-based, international upstream oil and gas company currently active in the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago. Primera Oil and Gas is the Trinidadian subsidiary of Touchstone.

such is the conjob ceo that we have, who just keeps trying to hide failures and talk about something else to get folks excited. now he's talking about venezuela. bottom line, a poor cr3 result will not break the company, but it will crash the sp back to 6-7p. and that's because it will say to the market that central doesn't have as much upside as we think. that our mgt team don't have a f @cking clue about geology anywhere on the island and basically sink a well and hope/pray they can drill it without issues, and that it will payback. we won't have cash to develop further until pricing changes kick in, at which point we will be slowly regaining production with every decent well, if they're decent. our debt pile is significantly more than our mcap, making any capital raise highly dilutive. we have a bunch of lying ****s runnign the show. the list goes on. so cr3 is a bl@@dy big well for the company. if it hits 5mmcf (net) we will regain double figures, and imo get to 12-13p. but what we really need to get the company back on track is a 10mmcf (net) well. this will get the government excited, and no doubt vat refunds will be recycled more quickly. we'll have headroom for our debt. and be able to sink a few more wells this year, which if successful, will take the sp back to the 20's. but the downside is quite ugly, and for a while. there's no hiding this.

data.author: John2727
data.content: G, I think you’re conflating three different things, which is exactly why these threads go in circles. Operating cash vs free cash flow You’re absolutely right that TXP has been FCF-negative during a heavy capex phase. That’s not controversial, and it’s been openly stated by management. But that’s a capital allocation choice, not a sign the underlying business can’t generate cash. TXP can cover debt service and opex from operations, and still be FCF-negative if it chooses to reinvest heavily. Those are not mutually exclusive. Debt service vs balance sheet optics. The point I made (and keep making) is narrower than the argument you’re rebutting. I’m not saying TXP is “financially strong” in a balance-sheet sense today. I am saying existing production covers debt servicing and running costs. That matters, because it means CR-3 is about upside and inflection, not insolvency. A poor CR-3 outcome does not automatically create a “zombie company” That distinction gets lost when everything is framed as binary success/failure. The share price doesn’t reflect “can the company pay its bills” It reflects, dilution risk, execution fatigue, credibility scars from past guidance and capital intensity vs timing. All fair points but they’re market psychology, not proof the operating base is broken. As for covenant waivers again, not unusual in a scale-up phase following a major acquisition. They’re uncomfortable, but not the same as being unable to service debt. But we’re not cash-dead, and CR-3 does not determine whether the lights stay on. CR-3 determines pricing uplift, speed of deleveraging and whether growth is self-funded or diluted. That’s the distinction I was making and not claiming everything is rosy. Happy to debate numbers, but it helps if we’re debating the same question.

data.author: G_G_G
data.content: no it's conjobbaay just talking **** again. i mean venezuela now, what a ****. john27, you of all people should be the last person talking about how we can cover this and that through cashflow. the number of times discord members have shouted down people with such numbers is quite ridiculous. and none of them have come remotely close to the appalling figures that have ended up being reported. if we were so financially sound, we wouldn't be sitting in single digits after drilling such a promising well. simple as that. as for the numbers you are quoting, there's a big difference between operating income and how much cash we're generating. here's your reality check: overview: based on the most recent rns filings (up to q3 2025, released in november 2025), touchstone exploration is currently in a "heavy investment" phase. while production is scaling up, free cash flow remains negative because capital expenditures (drilling and acquisitions) are currently outstripping the cash generated from operations. note on cash generation: the company uses "funds flow from operations" as its primary cash metric. free cash flow (fcf) here is estimated by subtracting capital expenditures from funds flow. as you can see, the fcf has been increasingly negative over the past 12 months as they ramp up drilling at cascadura. recent quarter analysis: q3 2025 the most recent quarter shows a company under temporary financial pressure but with growing asset scale: - net debt surge: debt climbed to $77.75 million, largely due to a $12.5 million convertible debenture and the earlier $30 million acquisition of the "central block." - production: averaged 5,141 boe/d. while this is an increase over q2, the "funds flow" dropped to just $0.74m due to higher financing costs (interest on that new debt) and higher taxes. - the "waiver": crucially, touchstone had to obtain a financial covenant waiver from its lender for the end of 2025, suggesting they are operating very close to their debt limits. next 12 months: outlook for 2026 - the health of the company over the next 12 months depends entirely on converting recent drilling into consistent cash: - revenue growth: analysts project revenue growth of ~49% as new wells like cascadura-5 and carapal ridge-3 (results announced jan 2026) contribute to the full-year total. - cash inflection: the company expects to generate roughly $22 million in funds flow for the full year 2025/2026. if they keep capital spending around the $23m mark (as budgeted), they will be roughly cash-flow neutral or slightly negative until the next major production step-change. - debt reduction: management’s goal is to bring net debt back down toward $30 million by the end of 2025/early 2026, though this relies on no further major acquisition spending. summary: touchstone is "asset rich but cash tight." they have successfully grown production, but the cost of that growth has pushed debt to a peak. they need a smooth, high-volume product

data.author: John2727
data.content: a few people still seem confused about cash flow and debt, so here it is in simple, real-world terms. we’re already covering debt comfortably today, before cr-3 pricing uplift. current position central block gas: 18–19 mmscf/d gross 13–14 mmscf/d net us$14–15m p.a. gas revenue this alone covers annual debt payments (us$5–6m) add cas-1 & cas-2 gas 6–7 mmscf/d gross 4.5–5 mmscf/d net us$5m p.a. additional gas revenue add cas-5 oil (small but real): modest volumes, but still ≈ us$3–4m p.a. net cash so before cr-3 pricing uplift, group operating cash is roughly: us$22–24m per year so……. debt is covered opex is covered txp is already cash-generative cr-3 is not about survival like some are suggesting. what changes once central block moves above 22 mmscf/d? meaning cr3 only needs to settle at 4 mmscf/d gas pricing steps up from us$3.0/mcf to us$3.6/mcf (after all costs) at 24 mmscf/d cb, that pricing uplift alone adds roughly us$3.7m per year and drops straight to cash debt is already covered today with cas production alone and cas-1, cas-2 and cas-5 mean txp is already running a surplus cr-3 + higher pricing turns that surplus into meaningful free cash flow. equity raises are **** and could have been done better but are about speed and scale, not keeping the lights on. that’s the bit that often gets missed. happy to be corrected but even with a +- 10% we’re looking in good shape to get straight into cr4 once cr3 is hooked up. (based on last financial statement)

data.author: Sturm
data.content: Where Millstone is wrong...,  implicitly asserting this: “Without success at Cas-4, Cas-5 and CR-3, the debt is not serviceable.” That is not supported by the numbers. Why that’s incorrect: Even excluding Cas-4 / Cas-5 / CR-3 success, Touchstone still has: Existing producing cash flow Cascadura + Central Block Enough to cover interest ~4–5× Structural tailwinds not tied to wells 2027 gas price uplift VAT recoveries (cash / bonds) Manageable debt profile No immediate principal cliff Issue is covenants and leverage, not liquidity collapse That means: Debt is serviceable But not comfortable aAnd not deleveraging meaningfully VAT recovery and gas price uplift are exogenous to Cas-4 / Cas-5 / CR-3. They change the balance sheet without drilling success. What happens to Millstones argument if any of the events happens: VAT or Gas price uplift? Debt becomes clearly serviceable Covenant pressure eases Dilution risk reduces materially ❌ Millstone’s claim that drilling success is required is weakened ❌ Debt stress is no longer binary 👉 VAT alone does not make Touchstone comfortable — but it breaks the “unserviceable” claim.

data.content: G_G_G Not a stretch.  The chances of a non-commercial CR-3 are significant.  At that point everything stops and you are probably in strategic review territory at best.  Good luck with that.  A marginally commercial CR-3 would still leave TXP a steep hill to climb. Only a very robust performance from CR-3 is going to re-establish a growth trajectory here.  I think you need to entirely tune out the fanboy narrative around CR-3 (remember how wrong they got Cas-5) and look again at the balance of risk and reward.  It looks like a coin toss to me, so I just don’t see the attraction.  It’s speculation, not investment. I think this could be a good year for O&G but there are better propositions out there.

data.author: ab76
data.content: More from Paul in this article - https://trinidadexpress.com/business/local/touchstone-ceo-sees-opportunity-in-venezuela/article_4b4f2e99-59f9-4360-b17c-fb97a21a70c6.html : “We’ve downsized a little bit in the last year and that is a result of some of the wells not performing as well as we originally thought, so we had to make those adjustments. But as we start to ramp up here with the new acquisition we’ve done, and as we do more drilling, we use more local content—which is also a tricky term in Trinidad, because local content can be ‘local content’ and ‘local local content’ right down to the neighbourhoods we operate in. As we move out of an area and into another, there is a perception that some of the jobs are lost, but generally, they get picked up wherever we’re moving to.” Baay said one of the major recent developments at the company has been the completed drilling of the Central Block, about which he said he was excited, despite the slow start; he predicted a busy 2026.

data.author: ab76
data.content: The relevant bit from the article sirmark referred to is: Touchstone Exploration’s Paul Baay agreed that the sector is in a good place, as he explained that the ministry’s acceleration of approvals had brought up the date of potential returns from the company’s recent drilling of onshore wells at Central Block. “I think the key thing there is, because we’re onshore, some of our projects can get turned around quicker, like we can physically drill a well and get it in production much quicker than some of these big offshore ones. So the new Government is recognising that and helped us with approvals, like certificates for environmental compliance,” Baay said. “We drilled the first well. We want to drill a second well, really quickly. That process, you know, used to be a nine-month process, and it’s been shrunk down. Now it looks like it’s going to be literally a couple of weeks, maybe a month.” Baay added that the company could see some returns from that activity by the end of February. “We drilled the first well in December at the central block, and that’s going to come on at the end of February. So you know that’s like, we’re not talking quarters here. We’re talking months and weeks from when we can drill a well to when we get it on production,” he said. Baay said, “Those are the kind of reaction times that I think the new Government is recognising and putting in place the necessary things that we see. So from our point of view, that saves us money and saves us time. From the Government’s point of view, that gets molecules on quicker for all of those suppliers that need them.” The full article is available at https://guardian.co.tt/business/energy-sector-optimistic-about-2026-6.2.2501152.bff3b02b0a

data.author: aligator
data.content: Well completion and flow testing are ongoing, with tie-in to the Central Block gas processing facility expected to be achieved by end March.  In the O&G industry, what happens during such periods is that those physically undertaking the  work/assessment become pregnant with inside knowledge and are aware that there are many outsiders willing to "obtain" such information for investment purposes, invariably for reward.  It is more than possible that this little sp recovery is down to the leak of such information, which suggests that CR-3 is looking good.  However, how many times over the past 2-3 years have we been in this situation, only to be told that wells have not either not met expectations or encountered problems or some other issue? That said, I am keeping my fingers crossed on this because, as I commented previously, success with CR-3 could see the sp tick up to ca 15p (which would reflect a 50% increase) but more bad news will crater the sp, possibly to below 5p.

data.author: Sturm
data.content: Ross... #PTAL has made plenty of serious mistakes — on a par with TXP, frankly. Several were genuinely existential. Off the top of my head: Paying dividends prematurely. Failing to hedge massive oil volumes while carrying heavy debt, despite explicit warnings. That one is hard to excuse. Nearly killed the company and diluted shareholders massively. The ONP oil sales terms — absurd. A structure that leaves risk on your books after the oil is supposedly “sold”. Handing out an enormous number of investor warrants. A “substantially oversubscribed” raise — to quote Manolo — is not a success when it results in dilution far beyond what was required. Issuing a high-cost bond that was roughly four times larger than needed, supposedly to fund acquisitions. No acquisitions followed. They didn’t even buy back the investor warrants (around 300m, IIRC). Promising to drill Block 107 at IPO, then repeatedly failing to deliver. Year after year of “next year, Rodney”. And as for the TRIN acquisition — I still struggle to see how anyone thought that was smart for TXP. No synergy, just added complexity layered onto the same cost base. Central Block, by contrast, is a masterclass in synergy — exactly what a good acquisition should look like.

data.author: Sturm
data.content: Ross... #PTAL has made plenty of serious mistakes — on a par with TXP, frankly. Several were genuinely existential. Off the top of my head: Paying dividends prematurely. Failing to hedge massive oil volumes while carrying heavy debt, despite explicit warnings. That one is hard to excuse. Nearly killed the company and diluted shareholders massively. The ONP oil sales terms — absurd. A structure that leaves risk on your books after the oil is supposedly “sold”. Handing out an enormous number of investor warrants. A “substantially oversubscribed” raise — to quote Manolo — is not a success when it results in dilution far beyond what was required. Issuing a high-cost bond that was roughly four times larger than needed, supposedly to fund acquisitions. No acquisitions followed. They didn’t even buy back the investor warrants (around 300m, IIRC). Promising to drill Block 107 at IPO, then repeatedly failing to deliver. Year after year of “next year, Rodney”. And as for the TRIN acquisition — I still struggle to see how anyone thought that was smart for TXP. No synergy, just added complexity layered onto the same cost base. Central Block, by contrast, is a masterclass in synergy — exactly what a good acquisition should look like.

data.author: Sturm
data.content: Ross... The question isn’t who’s felt luckiest over the last 20 months; it’s whether the current price reflects the forward risk/reward. Repeating “9p is about right” and invoking a vague risk of “going to zero” doesn’t make the case unless you explain how that happens — mechanically and financially. I’m not dismissing risk; I’m explicitly modelling it. If CR-3 fails, downside is limited to where we are now. If it lands even mid-case, the valuation moves materially. That asymmetry is the whole point. Calling that “going to zero risk” without showing a credible path to insolvency is assertion, not argument. Time will tell — but time tends to reward those who quantify probabilities, not those who rely on being “lucky”. If you have better things to do than explain your argument, that’s fine — but then don’t expect “trust me, I’ve been lucky” to carry any weight.

data.author: Sturm
data.content: Ross.... That’s a mischaracterisation, but exactly what anyone could expect from you. How's it going with answering the 14+ questions you've been asked to prove your POV? CR-3 isn’t about “short-term success”; it’s about re-rating optionality. The company can service debt and operate without CR-3 — what CR-3 changes is how quickly and how decisively the balance sheet and equity narrative improve. Calling it a “coin toss” ignores the asymmetry. A failed well caps downside near today’s valuation; a commercially successful well materially shifts cash flow, probabilities, and pricing assumptions — as we’ve just shown numerically. That’s not a gamble, it’s a skewed payoff. Saying “9p is about right” simply restates the current price, not a valuation. The market isn’t declaring CR-3 worthless; it’s withholding value until data arrives. That’s uncertainty pricing, not proof the reward is inadequate. If CR-3 lands anywhere near the mid-case, the maths moves quickly. If it doesn’t, value drops back to where it is now. That’s exactly why this isn’t a binary survival bet — it’s a de-risking catalyst with disproportionate upside.
data.thread_title: RE: RE: February is going to be a stinker !!!!

What you have here has been fairly described by others as a coin toss: unattractive either as an investment or a gamble.  The reward does not outweigh the risk: 9p is about right - the market gets it even if Discord doesn’t.

data.author: ab76
data.content: Touchstone's short term success is dependant upon a good CR3 result. Expectations are being managed, but the prediction last year (see for example the August 2025 presentation) was it would produce 10 million per day and more recently Touchstone has indicated that if four wells are added to Central Block this year production from that block alone could more than double (with the increase attracting a much higher price than existing production). If that happens, and we'll have a better idea once we get the CR3 results, the disasters of 2025 will be well behind us. There's also plenty of gas still to extract from Cascudura, but it makes sense to leave it to 2027 when much higher prices will apply once the existing contract expires. A bonus this year will be if there's a deep oil farm out and some drilling. That's difficult to predict, but after years of decline there's increasing interest in Trinidad (evidenced amongst other things by Exxon's return last August) perhaps in part because of the deep oil discoveries in Guyana etc and the new government's red-tape cutting should help too. Add in the boost from the compressor in May/June and a VAT refund, and it may well be a very good year. Nothing's guaranteed though.
